content.description: This route begins immediately to the right of bolts to Baghdad it sends a straight face with the crux towards the top. Rock solid with very pleasant climbing.
content.location: This route begins immediately to the right of bolts to Baghdad it sends a straight face with the crux towards the top. Rock solid very pleasant climbing.

content.description:
A long, sustained route with fun movements on less than clean rock. Doesn't have any distinct crux. Climbing goes slowly trying to find secure holds with no dirt or moss. By the top you may be pretty worn out considering it's only rated 5.7. The end of the climb traverses slightly to the left and shares anchors with

The Lowe Route

.
content.protection:
12 bolts followed by two double-ring anchors. Shares an anchor with

The Lowe Route

and possibly the 12th as well.
content.location: It's the 7th bolted line starting from the left (North) end of Mammoth Wall. Start climbing below the belay platform.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Starts on  large edges that thin out as you get to the 7th or 8th bolt. Move to the right to avoid this thin section directly below the P1 anchor. You should be able to just reach bolt #11 and the P1 anchor far to your left from the easier terrain.

Pitch 2: Continue heading up and to your right from the P1 anchor to avoid the small roof on

Habib roohi

. When you reach the large dihedral/crack use a combination of edges, liebacks, and jamming to reach the top.

If you have two 50+ (or one 100+) meter ropes you can easily set up a toprope. Follow instructions for accessing the top of Mammoth Wall for TR setup approach.

If you don't plan on lowering down back down, you could lead this as a single, LONG pitch with a 60m and your 2nd could just follow on the other end of the rope, then walk off. Alternatively, you could carry/trail a 2nd 60 m line to set up your rappel.
content.protection:
10 bolts to P1 anchor (Fixe Ring + bolted chain). There is an extra bolt at this anchor to facilitate a single pitch lead.

P2 TR anchor (two rusty, but solid bolted chains + 1 bolt hanger). For TR setup, there's an extra bolt 9' back from the edge next to a bush to protect you while setting up the TR.. The first 11 bolts and both anchors are shared with

Habib roohi

.
content.location: This is the 22nd bolted line from the left (North) end of Mammoth Wall. It's the third bolted line from the right (South) end.

content.description: This is a beautiful route starting to the right of curry chicken about 10 feet heading up a ramp to A step  face. Continue up  the steep face following the bolt line to the anchors. Small holds  and Hi steps make for some excellent climbing.

P1

(5.10b)  - Face climbing to a hanging belay. An easy start past 4 bolts to a dark hole on the face. Move right onto the steeper face for 4 more bolts to a two chain hanging belay.

P2

(5.11b) - Move left and climb to the right of the crack past 8 bolts to a ledge and a 2 chain anchor, or climb past 1 more bolt reach chains on top.
content.protection:
P1

- 8 bolts to chain anchors

P2

- 8 bolts to chain anchors

P3

- 1 bolt to chain anchors (could combine P2 & P3)

To descend use two 60m ropes to rappel to the base, or walk off.
content.location: 4th bolt line from the right (south) on Mammoth Wall.

content.description: Just to the right of hands n socks . The route begins  on the face below a roof 20 feet off the deck. Climb to the face to the base of the roof traversed left slightly then climb over the roof to the by moving right using good holds .  Then climb straight up the face  to the anchor.

This route is  number three and is the first route to the right of Semper Fi . Climb past an obscure  old pin following the bolt line to the

a small part roof then move directly over the roof up the face to the anchors

Pitch 1: Starts on easy terrain (5.8-ish) over large edges that thin out as you get to the 7th or 8th bolt and becomes quite smooth at the P1 anchor and 11th bolt.

Pitch 2: Head from the P1 anchor straight up an over a small roof, then continue on thin edges to the top anchor.

If you have 2 ropes (or a single 100 meter) you can set up a toprope.

If you don't plan on lowering down back down, you could lead this as a single, LONG pitch with a 60m. (Or you could carry/trail a 2nd 60 m line to set up your rappel.)
content.protection:
10 bolts to P1 anchor (Fixe Ring + bolted chain). There is an extra bolt at this anchor to facilitate a single pitch lead.

6 or 7 more bolts to P2 TR anchor (two rusty, but solid bolted chains + 1 bolt hanger). For TR setup, there's an extra bolt 9' back from the edge next to a bush to protect you while setting up the TR. First 11 bolts and both anchors are shared with

Merciful Passing

.
content.location:
22nd bolted line from the left (North) end of Mammoth wall. 3rd bolted line from right (South) end.

The top anchors are about 80 ft north of the south end. There are some rocks set in cement along the edge of the cliff just north of the anchors. It's the 3rd anchor North of the south end (as of 11/2019, anyway).

content.description:
Route begins  next to the only tree along bottom of the mammoth wall.  Climb directly up from the platform then go slightly right you’ll then enter into a crack system that’s bolted. The crux is entering into the crack system. Try to get the no hands rest by doing the knee jam. Very good climbing above that using the crack system good hand locks.  I find this very pleasant climbing. The loose rock in this area is common. This will all disappear as people climate. My guess is it’s had only a few climb  since this was put up years ago. With time I find this style of climbing to be very appealing esp. as it cleans via traffic. I would give it three stars. Bolts replaced about every 6 feet apart.

A nerve-wracking affair with apparently good rock in places, that then sounds hollow when you get there.

Less-than-vertical with mostly positive holds; the climbing isn't bad, but you worry about the rock, the bolts in the rock, etc.

Loose stuff abounds off the bolt line, but the actual line itself isn't too bad.

Choss-haters need not apply.
content.location: Starts about half-way up the slope on the left side of the wall. It ends up under an obvious flake, which is in turn to the left of and below a very large flake/roof.

content.description: To the right of Hep you , number  five on the photo,  climb up the face below the roof work out of the roof through some broken rock straight up the face to the anchors
Immediately to the right of pipe bombs away. This is route number eight on the photo. This climbs up and obvious face and ends at the top of divine intervention under a small overhang. Good climbing

This route is a package deal starting at the far left of the mammoth it sends a ramp to a common anchor between simplify and boots to Baghdad. The rock is solid and makes for some very interesting climbing.
content.location: The furthest left route marked number one in the photo

content.description:
Climbs mostly large positive edges with the occasional side pull or gaston and even some undercling/lieback at the finish. Rock seemed mostly solid enough to pull on. Make sure you belayer (and spectators) are to the left (uphill) of the route for their safety.

CAUTION: The final feature sounds  VERY HOLLOW! Make sure there is nobody (especially your belayer) in the fall line from the anchor. It's the flake that you pull on in an undercling/lieback for the last few moves, and then you stand on it when working at the anchor. It's definitely not confidence-inspiring doing the undercling/lieback moves or  standing on it. If this came loose it could easily kill anybody below and maybe even you if it lands on your rope on the way down.
content.protection: 6 bolts to Fixe Ring Anchor and Bolted Chain.
content.location:
21st bolted line from the left (North) end of Mammoth wall. 4th bolted line from the right (South) end.

The top anchors are about 80 ft north of the south end. There are some rocks set in cement along the edge of the cliff just north of the anchors. It's the 3rd anchor North of the south end (as of 11/2019, anyway).
